content.title: ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS OF CLEAN ENERGY TECHNOLOGY DEPLOYMENT
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2

content.text: Lesson 2 Overview

As the global transition to renewable energy gains momentum in response to climate change and the need to reduce dependence on fossil fuels, it becomes increasingly crucial to thoroughly assess the environmental impacts associated with these renewable energy technologies, especially vis-Ã -vis the impacts of fossil fuels they are replacing A key aspect of this evaluation involves comparing the lifecycle GHG emissions of different energy technologies. Lifecycle assessments offer insights into the total carbon footprint of energy sources, encompassing emissions throughout their entire lifecycle, including extraction, manufacturing, transportation, and disposal. While all electricity generation methods produce GHG emissions, fossil fuels demonstrate notably higher emissions intensity compared to renewable energies.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: habitat fragmentation mitigation
concepts.body: Habitat fragmentation mitigation refers to strategies and actions taken to reduce the negative impacts of habitat fragmentation, which occurs when large habitats are divided into smaller, isolated patches, often due to human activities. This can include creating wildlife corridors, restoring habitats, and implementing land-use planning to maintain connectivity between habitats.

concepts.title: lifecycle assessment (lca)
concepts.body: Lifecycle assessment (LCA) is a systematic process for evaluating the environmental impacts of a product or service throughout its entire life cycle, from raw material extraction to production, use, and disposal.

concepts.title: renewable technology recycling
concepts.body: Renewable technology recycling refers to the process of recovering and reprocessing materials from renewable energy technologies, such as solar panels and wind turbines, to reduce waste and promote sustainability.

content.text: Three layers of supply-side challenges need to be addressed to ensure rapid and secure energy transitions

However, the environmental considerations surrounding renewable energy generation extend beyond GHG emissions alone. While renewable energy sources like solar and wind power offer cleaner alternatives to fossil fuels, they present environmental challenges related to land use, habitat disruption, water consumption, and materials extraction. These broader environmental impacts demand thorough examination and consideration as we navigate the transition to renewable energy. In this section, we delve deeper into these environmental concerns associated with renewable energy generation to gain a comprehensive understanding of its ecological impact.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 3 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Impacts of Wind Turbines

content.text: Wind power stands out as a low-impact alternative to traditional energy sources like fossil fuels and nuclear power generation, with minimal GHG emissions (Miller et al., 2019; Owusu & Asumadu-Sarkodie, 2016). Nonetheless, the widespread deployment of wind turbines has sparked apprehensions regarding its environmental implications, particularly concerning human well-being and local ecosystems (Sarkodie & Strezov, 2018).
Habitats

Wind projects can disrupt habitats and contribute to soil erosion and drying through construction activities, operational effects, and changes in land use. Recent researches show that wind turbines can significantly reduce soil moisture within wind farms. This drought effect varies by season and wind direction (Wang et al., 2023.) The soil-drying effect is particularly pronounced in grassland areas, where it may impact local ecosystems and vegetation health. Mitigation measures include careful site selection to avoid sensitive habitats, the use of erosion control practices like replanting vegetation around turbines, and the implementation of buffer zones to protect wildlife corridors. A deeper understanding of seasonal and directional soil impacts is essential to help manage these effects on grassland ecosystems, along with ongoing monitoring to adapt management strategies as needed.
Birds

Wind turbines can pose a collision risk to migrating birds, especially during peak migration seasons when billions of birds fill the skies. The spinning blades can be particularly hazardous in areas of high winds, where migratory routes converge. Researchers have proposed various solutions to mitigate this issue. One effective method involves improving blade visibility by painting them black or with black and white stripes, significantly reducing bird fatalities. Using artificial intelligence to detect approaching birds and powering down turbines to prevent collisions is another innovative approach. By implementing these strategies and carefully situating wind farms to avoid high-risk areas for bird collisions, the impact of wind energy development on migrating birds can be minimized while still harnessing the benefits of RE.
Local Climate

The proliferation of wind power installations has prompted concerns about local climate variations, exemplified by instances such as droughts reported in Inner Mongolia (Liu et al., 2024). Studies carried out in wind-rich regions like the San Gorgonio wind zone indicate that large turbines can influence local temperatures. Although the severity of these effects necessitates further observation, simulations suggest that they are predominantly regional rather than global in scope. Environmental engineers have also raised concerns about turbulence around turbines and its potential contribution to long-distance climate changes. Continuous monitoring and advanced research are essential in this regard.
Wellbeing

The proximity of wind turbines to residential areas can result in various adverse effects on human life, notably disturbances arising from noise levels and visual impacts, including the dominant presence of large structures on the landscape, may contribute to a sense of intrusion and aesthetic dissatisfaction. An additional concern is shadow flicker, which occurs when rotating turbine blades cast intermittent shadows on nearby properties. This flickering effect can cause discomfort, distraction, and in some cases, stress for residents. Prolonged exposure to shadow flicker may impact mental well-being, especially for individuals sensitive to visual stimuli. Technological solutions, such as software that limits turbine operation during peak shadow flicker times, can further reduce these impacts. Strategic landscaping, including the planting of trees or installation of visual barriers, can also help mitigate visual intrusion, fostering a more balanced coexistence between wind energy infrastructure and local communities.
Noise

The noise generated by wind turbines, categorized into aerodynamic and mechanical types, has sparked debate. While the impact of mechanical noise lacks definitive evidence, its low-frequency nature may disrupt human lives. Research conducted by Miller and Keith (2018) has established a correlation between wind turbine sound pressure levels and adverse effects on nearby residents, potentially leading to sleep disorders and hearing loss. Furthermore, the low-frequency aerodynamic noise from wind turbines may pose health risks, including harm to the vestibular system. Proposed mitigation measures include situating turbines at least 2 km away from residential areas or optimizing house construction to minimize interference

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2 Impacts of Solar Power

content.text: The environmental impact of solar energy includes several factors, primarily land use and greenhouse gas emissions from the manufacturing and transportation of panels. Additionally, the use of hazardous materials in production processes contributes to solar power environmental footprint.
Hazardous material

The Photo Voltaics (PV) manufacturing process akin to most clean energy technology involves hazardous materials like acids and chemicals, posing risks to workers and potential environmental threats if not handled and disposed of properly. Additionally, thin-film PV cells contain more toxic materials, emphasizing the importance of proper management to avoid environmental and health hazards (National Renewable Energy Laboratory, 2012).
Land use

Solar power generation requires large areas of land for solar panel installations, potentially leading to habitat destruction and loss of biodiversity. Reports indicate that solar systems, including PV and Concentrated Solar Power (CSP), have high energy land-use intensity compared to other energy technologies, with projected substantial land requirements for future growth (Van de Ven et al., 2021) The potential land requirements and related land use change emissions of solar energy. Innovative approaches like dual-angle solar arrays may mitigate land use impact.
Water consumption

Water usage varies depending on plant design and cooling technology, with CSP plants requiring significant amounts of water for cooling, albeit with alternatives like dry cooling to reduce consumption (Tawalbeh et al., 2020).
GHG emissions

Emissions primarily arise from the energy-intensive processes involved in extracting and refining raw materials, such as silicon, and producing photovoltaic cells. Transporting panels from manufacturing sites to installation locations further adds to the carbon footprint, especially for projects in remote areas. However, advancements in manufacturing efficiency and the adoption of cleaner energy sources for production are gradually reducing these emissions, enhancing the overall sustainability of solar power.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 3 | Lesson 2 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Impacts of Hydropower

content.text: The environmental impacts of hydropower, particularly concerning the construction of large storage or pumped storage plants, are significant and multifaceted.
Ecosystems

One prominent consequence is the alteration of natural river systems, where blocking or diverting river flows disrupts vital migration routes for fish. This interruption poses a severe threat to fish populations, hindering their ability to reach breeding grounds and leading to a decline in overall numbers. Despite attempts to mitigate these effects using fish ladders, these solutions often fall short of adequately supporting fish migrations. Moreover, the damming of rivers frequently results in diminished downstream water and sediment flows, depriving wildlife of essential habitats and nutrients. This disruption not only threatens the biodiversity of river ecosystems but also undermines the well-being of downstream animal populations reliant on these resources (Augustine et al., 2012)
Indirect GHG emissions

Reservoirs act as carbon sinks, trapping organic matter that decomposes and releases greenhouse gases such as carbon dioxide and methane into the water. While hydroelectric plants themselves do not directly emit greenhouse gases during operation, the life-cycle emissions associated with reservoir creation can be substantial, particularly in tropical areas or temperate peatlands where decomposition rates are higher. This underscores the importance of carefully considering the environmental ramifications of hydropower projects and adopting site-specific mitigation strategies to minimize their ecological footprint (Source: National Academy of Sciences. 2010)

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Lifecycle GHG Assessments Reveal the True Environmental Footprint of Energy Technologies
takeaways.description: While renewable energy sources like wind and solar have significantly lower lifecycle greenhouse gas emissions compared to fossil fuels, a comprehensive evaluation must consider the entire supply chainâfrom extraction and manufacturing to disposal. This ensures that the transition to renewables does not inadvertently introduce new environmental challenges.

takeaways.title: Renewable Energy Deployment Must Address Localized Environmental and Social Impacts
takeaways.description: The deployment of renewable energy technologies, such as wind turbines and solar farms, can lead to localized environmental disruptions, including habitat destruction, noise pollution, and changes in local climate patterns. Mitigation strategies, such as optimizing turbine placement, improving blade visibility, and using dual-angle solar arrays, are essential to minimize these impacts while maximizing the benefits of clean energy.

takeaways.title: Hydropowerâs Ecological Trade-offs Require Site-Specific Mitigation Strategies
takeaways.description: Large-scale hydropower projects, while low in direct emissions, can significantly alter river ecosystems, disrupt fish migration, and release indirect greenhouse gases from reservoirs. Site-specific mitigation measures, such as improved fish passage systems and careful reservoir management, are crucial to balancing the ecological trade-offs and ensuring that hydropower remains a sustainable energy option.
